<h2>
<a href="#introduction_to_the_"ruby_software_manager"_project
_rsm_formerly_called_"ruby_build_tools"_rbt"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Introduction to the "Ruby Software Manager" Project
  (RSM), formerly called "Ruby Build Tools" (RBT)
</h2>
<p class="default">
<script>
$(function() {

  if (typeof global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === 'undefined' || global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === null) {
    $( "#drag_pn2lohj" ).draggable()
  }
  else {
    if (global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop) {
      $( "#drag_pn2lohj" ).draggable()
    }
    else {
      $( "#drag_pn2lohj" ).draggable({ disabled: true })
    }
  }
});


</script>

<img src="https://i.imgur.com/PN2lOHj.png" class="round_black3 mar8px marl2em" id="drag_pn2lohj" draggable="true">
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Welcome to the <span style="color: darkgreen; font-weight: bold">Ruby
    Software Manager</span> project, also called the <b>RSM suite</b> -
    <b>getting work done</b>! <b>Making compiling and installing
    software great again</b>. \o/</span>
<br>
</p>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">This <b>documentation</b> here attempts to detail the
    various objectives for the RSM project, including its
    history, as well as how people may benefit from the
    project.</span>
<br>
</p>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Let's now jump right into the main goals of this
    project - the <b>primary objectives</b>.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#the_primary_objective_of_the_rsm_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>The primary objective of the RSM project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">The <span style="color: darkblue; font-weight:bold ">primary objective</span>
    for the <b>RSM project</b> is <b>to support and help users whenever the need
    arises to install software, on a given computer system</b>. For instance,
    if the user wishes to install or compile a specific program.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The RSM project should remain flexible for such a use case. For
    example, say that there is a <b>source archive</b> available at
    the following remote URL:</span>
<br>
<br>
<a href="https:/github.com/htop-dev/htop/releases/download/3.3.0/htop-3.3.0.tar.xz" class="BOLD marl2em">
https://github.com/htop-dev/htop/releases/download/3.3.0/htop-3.3.0.tar.xz
</a>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">We would like to support the following commandline invocation, in
    order to compile this source archive (a .tar.xz tarball) from source:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
rsm https://github.com/htop-dev/htop/releases/download/3.3.0/htop-3.3.0.tar.xz
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The RSM suite will do various steps to achieve this. Specifically it
    will do at the least the following steps:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
(1) download the remote archive locally
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
(2) extract the tarball
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
(3) prepare the archive for compilation
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
(4) try to compile the program at hand
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
(5) report all findings that are relevant to the user [SUCSESS / FAILURE]
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In the ideal outcome, this remote tarball has been downloaded
    and then compiled successfully (aka <b>installed successfull</b>).</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This is not the only use case, of course.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If the remote URL is a binary package, then RSM should install
    it. If it is a local archive, then this should be installed as
    well.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This basically sums up the primary objective of the RSM suite.
    Let's next have a look at secondary objectives for this
    project.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#the_secondary_objectives_of_the_rsm_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>The secondary objectives of the RSM project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">The <b>RSM project</b> should help in regards to users wishing to
    maintain the software on their computer system in general.
    <b>RSM</b> thus needs to be able to act as a layer that
    can be helpful to the user, no matter the underlying
    operating system.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Various additional scripts are available that aid in
    various situations. For instance, one script can modify
    the PREFIX used in a Makefile. This allows the user to
    quickly use any other prefix variable, irrespective 
    over as to whether that Makefile supports it or not.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#support_for_different_operating_systems_by_the_rsm_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Support for different operating systems by the RSM project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">The primary operating system for the RSM suite is <b>Linux</b>,
    that is the <b>Linux operating systems</b> (henceforthwith
    simply called <b>Linux</b> in this document.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Linux is, in this regard, a first-class citizen. Everything
    pertaining to the RSM project will be tested and developed
    first and foremost on Linux.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">However had, other operating systems than Linux should also be
    supported. Whenever ruby works on a given operating system, the
    RSM suite will attempt to support that operating system. This
    may require some changes every now and then, though, as different
    operating systems have different features. For instance, <b>HaikuOS</b>
    favours a filesystem that is not easily supported by Ruby.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Additionally, when we refer to allowing a user to install
    software, this typically refers to taking the <b>source code</b>
    and compiling this source code - in other words: <b>to simply
    compile the program</b> at hand, from a <b>remote URL</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">While the <b>primary platform</b> for the <b>RSM project</b>
    is predominantly the <b>Linux</b> platform, whenever possible
    support for <b>other platforms</b> will be added as well. In
    fact, it is a secondary goal for the RSM project to support
    <b>all</b> platforms ruby is able to run on in the long term.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">How realistic it is to reach that goal is another matter,
    but as a goal RSM will eventually try to support as many
    different operating systems as possible, provided that
    ruby can run on such a system.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">As mentioned already, <b>Linux</b> is the <b>main target
    OS</b> for the RSM project, so things will always be
    tested on <b>Linux</b> first. Most development for
    the SoftwareManager-project does indeed take place
    on a Linux system currently.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Ideally, in the future, we could reach a state where we
    can test the SoftwareManager suite on less commonly used
    systems as well, such as <b>HaikuOS</b> or <b>ReactOS</b>
    to name only a few here. And, of course, the more popular
    ones such as OSX or Microsoft's Windows suite as well,
    naturally. Windows is the second operating system
    that SoftwareManager will support, by the way; it
    is less well-tested than the Linux-specific code of
    the SoftwareManager-project.</span>
<br>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#the_history_of_the_softwaremanager_project_rsm_"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOKUMENT.png" class="marr12px">The History of the SoftwareManager Project (RSM).
</h2>
<p class="default" id="history_of_the_rsm_project">
<span class="l1em">Back in the days - and I still am of this opinion even
    today - I thought that shell scripts ultimately tend to grow
    in complexity way faster and steeper than equivalent code
    writte in other, better programming languages.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">They also lean towards becoming really ugly, which makes
    it hard to further extend them with more code, at which point
    sooner or later maintaining them becomes a burden.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">When maintaining code becomes hard to maintain, you often
    start to lose interest and eventually cease maintaining it
    or adding anything new to it. This was the case the with
    Linux distribution called GNU Sorcery - all their recipes
    were written in shell scripts.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Back in 2004 or so, I was using GoboLinux, and while
    the shell scripts used in GoboLinux were fairly elegant,
    I did not understand them at all. So I decided to
    re-create the logic found in those shell scripts, but
    primarily in ruby, storing the instructions in
    .yml (YAML) files.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#specifying_another_source_location"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Specifying another source location
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Normally all source archives are stored into
    <b>/home/x/src/</b> - or, rather, the variable the user
    set in the configuration file. (On my home system this
    is the directory I use for <b>keeping all source-archives</b>.)</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">But is this always the case, that a user keeps all source
    archives within a single directory? Of course not. Sometimes
    the user may want to <b>use another source location</b>. Precisely
    due to this reason, a commandline flag exists, to allow specifying
    the target path to another directory that is to be used as source
    archive. That commandline-flag is called
    <b>--use-this-source-location=</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">An example for using this follows, in order to make use
    of the path <b>/depot/j/gcc-12.3.0.tar.xz</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  ry gcc ntrad --use-this-source-location=/depot/j/gcc-12.3.0.tar.xz
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#specifying_another_programs_directory"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Specifying another programs directory
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">On my home setup, the programs-directory I use is <b>/home/Programs/</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">GoboLinux uses the directory /Programs/ as the programs-directory.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Some users may want to use another directory, such as
    <b>/opt/</b>. We thus need flexibility here.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The user needs a way to <b>designate a different programs
    directory</b>. This is done via the <b>commandline-flag</b>
    <b>--use-this-programs-dir=</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Invocation examples:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry htop --ntrad --use-this-program-dir=/opt
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry htop --ntrad --use-this-programs-dir=/opt
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will become the programs directory for the current
    compilation run. So, if compilation succeeds, the
    user may then have the AppDir at <b>/opt/Htop/3.3.0/</b>.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#obtaining_the_number_of_registered_programs"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Obtaining the number of registered programs
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">The <b>number of registered programs</b> in the
    SoftwareManager-project can be obtained via the
    commandline, by issuing any of the following commandline
    instructions:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --registered_programs?
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --n_programs?
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry registered_programs?
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The number of registered programs can be queried via
    the commandline as well, like in this way:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --n_programs?
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Although the output may be a little bit different.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This would then output something such as this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
→ 3330 programs registered as of 30.01.2018.
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
→ 3414 programs registered as of 18.09.2018.
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
→ 3635 programs registered as of 01.12.2019.
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
→ 3656 programs registered as of 12.01.2020.
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
→ 3846 programs registered as of 28.02.2025.
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">(The format may be a bit different to the above,
    but the information content is the same.)</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#static_compilation"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Static Compilation
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">It is possible to compile an application statically, by
    passing <b>static</b> to the main class <b>SoftwareManager
    (software_manager.rb)</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Specific example:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry make static --ntrad
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that this will not work for every program.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In the event that you, on the commandline, try to enable
    static compilation, and the yaml file specifies otherwise, such as
    via a configure switch like --disable-static, we will ignore the
    latter option and allow the user to specifically overrule this
    setting. The SoftwareManager-project always assumes that the
    user knows what he or she is doing.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that you can also zero these flags via a
    commandlie option:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry strace --no-compile-time-flags
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry strace --plain
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This option means that all CFLAGS etc... will be
    ignored altogether; that is, they will set to an
    empty again.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#using_a_different_set_of_configure_options"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Using a different set of configure-options
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Sometimes you may want to overrule, on the commandline,
    the configure options that are to be used by a program.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can do so via the switch
    <b>--use-these-configure-options=</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Usage example:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
--use-these-configure-options="--enable-shared --enable-bootstrap --enable-languages=c,c++,lto,objc,fortran --enable-threads=posix --enable-checking=release --enable-objc-gc --with-system-zlib --enable-libstdcxx-dual-abi --with-default-libstdcxx-abi=gcc4-compatible --disable-libunwind-exceptions --enable-__cxa_atexit --enable-libssp --enable-lto --disable-install-libiberty --with-gnu-ld --verbose --with-arch-directory=amd64 --disable-gtktest --disable-multilib --target=x86_64-slackware-linux --build=x86_64-slackware-linux --host=x86_64-slackware-linux"
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Complete usage example:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gcc --use-these-configure-options="--enable-shared --enable-bootstrap --enable-languages=c,c++,lto,objc,fortran --enable-threads=posix --enable-checking=release --enable-objc-gc --with-system-zlib --enable-libstdcxx-dual-abi --with-default-libstdcxx-abi=gcc4-compatible --disable-libunwind-exceptions --enable-__cxa_atexit --enable-libssp --enable-lto --disable-install-libiberty --with-gnu-ld --verbose --with-arch-directory=amd64 --disable-gtktest --disable-multilib --target=x86_64-slackware-linux --build=x86_64-slackware-linux --host=x86_64-slackware-linux"
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry poppler --use-these-configure-options="--enable-xpdf-headers"
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#disabling_the_use_of_cookbook_aliases"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Disabling the use of cookbook aliases
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">The cookbooks submodule, part of the SoftwareManager-project,
    makes use of several aliases to program names. This is mostly
    a convenience feature.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Sometimes this may lead to unexpected or unwanted results,
    such as when you want to compile program <b>a</b>, but the
    cookbooks-submodule automatically attempts to renames the
    program to <b>b</b> instead.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In order to avoid situations similar to this, a
    commandline-option exists for the main SoftwareManager
    class.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Invoke it like so:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry sdlttf --do-not-use-cookbook-aliases
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry sdlttf --do-not-use-cookbook-alias
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will specifically disable making use of
    cookbook-aliases for the current compilation run.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#compiling_via_the_rootprefix_option"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Compiling via the --rootprefix option
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Using the <b>--rootprefix</b> is exactly identical
    to passing the following flag:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
--prefix=/
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Nothing more than that.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The option was added in <b>November 2021</b> because I needed
    to compile all coreutils binaries into the /bin/ subdirectory
    on my home setup, and I needed these to be compiled statically,
    to avoid any problems during reboot when some shared libraries
    can not be found.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The exact command I used was:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry coreutils --static --rootprefix
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#installingcompiling_the_various_xcb_components"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Installing/Compiling the various xcb components
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">If you, like me, get tired of installing the various
    xorg-related <b>xcb components</b> then the following
    command should be of help here:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --compile-xcb-components
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will install the xcb-components in the correct
    order (actually it will compile the xcb-components).</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Aliases exist for this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --compile-the-xcb-components
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --compile-all-the-xcb
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --compile-xcb
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#program_versions"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Program Versions
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can overrule the version specified in the cookbook yaml file
    from the commandline. To do this, look at the following two examples:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nano --version=2.1.9
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nano --version=2.2.2
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nano --version=2.4.3
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gtk+ --version=2.24.29
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Do note that this has a chance to fail right
    now, i.e. if the remote mirror does not have
    this specific version, or if you do not
    have this program available locally.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can also use a <b>slight shortcut</b>:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nano --v=2.4.3
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">And an even shorter variant is to just give
    the leading name, and have the SoftwareManager
    script just pick one that fits:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry python --2
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can also use a more complete copy-paste
    version setting (like you copy, then paste
    the full name), like this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nano --version=pango-1.24.2.tar.bz2
</span><br>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#searching_for_something"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Searching for something
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">To search for something, do this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry ruby search
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">To find a specific list of packages, do this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  ry pyt*
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The * will tell us that we intend to find all
    packages starting with "pyt".</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This can work with single letters too, that is - if you
    wish to discover all programs that are registered in the
    Cookbooks project starting with a, you can do:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry e*
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The "<b>*</b>" is the important token here that
    will trigger this functionality.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Be careful though if you use a shell like Bash or
    Zsh - the * can be expanded by the shell.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#prefix_tag"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Prefix Tag
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can specify a different prefix to use when compiling
    a program.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">To do this, do:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gimp --prefix=$J
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gimp --prefix=/opt
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Some nifty shortcuts exist. For example, to compile
    gimp into a standalone directory, into
    /Programs/Gimp/LatestVersion, you can do:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gimp ntrad
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gimp non_traditional
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Please also note that you can use the Option <b>noprefix</b>
    to avoid using <b>any</b> specific prefix. (This is the same
    as passing --prefix=/usr/local though on GNU systems.)</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Do note that you can also use "compound-prefixes". These
    are prefixes such as /Programs/Xfce/4.12, where you may want
    to put all xfce-related programs into.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Syntax for this functionality goes like this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry xfce4panel --prefix=:xfce
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In order for this to work, an environment variable
    called XFCE_PREFIX may have to exist. If such an
    environment variable does not exist, then the
    program_version is guessed. I recommned to set such a
    prefix variant.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The leading : is important here - do not forget
    it.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#copy_the_whole_yaml_database_"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Copy the whole yaml database.
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can copy the whole yaml database by issuing:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry x copy_yaml
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#gobolinux_recipes"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Gobolinux Recipes
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">In order to create Gobolinux Recipes for i.e. python, do
    this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  ry python goborecipe
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  ry python --goborecipe
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Take note that this will create the recipe in the current
    working directory.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#class_softwaremanageractioncookbooksmultiurldisplayer"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>class SoftwareManager::Action::Cookbooks::MultiUrlDisplayer
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em"><b>class SoftwareManager::Action::Cookbooks::MultiUrlDisplayer</b>
    can be used to quickly show several programs and their associated
    remote URLs to their respective source archive on the commandline.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In order for this to work, naturally, these have to be part
    of a component, and registered in the cookbooks.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Since as of April 2024 this class is now part of the
    Actionsubmodule, and thus <b>an actionable component
    of the SoftwareManager suite</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Let's look at a specific usage example to demonstrate
    this functionality:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
action(:MultiUrlDisplayer, ARGV)
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
action(:MultiUrlDisplayer, 'kde-plasma5')
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
action(:MultiUrlDisplayer, 'plasma5')
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
action(:MultiUrlDisplayer, 'audio_suite')
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.action(:MultiUrlDisplayer, :audio_suite)
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Or from the commandline, via <b>multi_url_displayer</b>:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  multi_url_displayer plasma5
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The output will show all remote URLs of, for
    example, the KDE5 plasma components.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Example listing:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
plasmabrowserintegration:    https://download.kde.org/stable/plasma/5.19.4/plasma-browser-integration-5.19.4.tar.xz
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
plasmanano:                  https://download.kde.org/stable/plasma/5.19.4/plasma-nano-5.19.4.tar.xz
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
plasmaphonecomponents:       https://download.kde.org/stable/plasma/5.19.4/plasma-phone-components-5.19.4.tar.xz
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
kwaylandserver:              https://download.kde.org/stable/plasma/5.19.4/kwayland-server-5.19.4.tar.xz
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">On my computer system the output this will generate is
    as follows (as an image):</span>
<br>
<script>
$(function() {

  if (typeof global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === 'undefined' || global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === null) {
    $( "#drag_vc3zfyt" ).draggable()
  }
  else {
    if (global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop) {
      $( "#drag_vc3zfyt" ).draggable()
    }
    else {
      $( "#drag_vc3zfyt" ).draggable({ disabled: true })
    }
  }
});


</script>

<img src="https://i.imgur.com/vC3Zfyt.png" class="round_black4" id="drag_vc3zfyt" style="margin: 1em; margin-left: 3em;" draggable="true">
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you are only interested in the raw URL entries, on the
    right side, without the leading name, such as when you wish
    to use wget to batch-download this easily, try any of the
    following variants from the commandline:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
multi_url_displayer plasma5 --show-only-URLs
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
multi_url_displayer plasma5 --only-URLs
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
multi_url_displayer plasma5 --show-only-urls
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
multi_url_displayer plasma5 --raw
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#the_entry_status_of_the_project_in_a_cookbooks_yml_file"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>The entry status_of_the_project in a cookbooks .yml file
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">In <b>June 2023</b> the entry <b>status_of_the_project</b> was
    added.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Possible values include:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
- outdated
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
- possibly outdated
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
- low maintenance
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
- actively maintained
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This is somewhat experimental for now. The key idea is to
    indicate the maintenance health of a project. Most will
    default to the value <b>actively maintained</b>, so this
    entry is primarily useful when a project was abandoned.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#installing_older_versions_of_programs"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Installing older versions of programs
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">What if the user wishes to install an older version of, say,
    <b>python</b>?</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The corresponding <b>cookbook.yml</b> file normally
    "supports" only the version that is specified in
    <b class="lightblue">archive_name:</></b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For example, if you jump to the "python:" entry in the
    cookbook.yml file, you will see that its version is
    2.5.1 or something like that.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This can be changed permanently by writing another
    name/version there, into that file called python.yml.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Because editing of various cookbook.yml files can be a
    little annoying, and because flexibility is nice to have,
    there exists another way to specify a different version
    manually on the commandline:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
compile python --version=2.4.1
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This works with every version, even "newer" ones.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The name of the version should however be part of
    the filename.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For more information about this, and an even <b>easier
    way</b>, jump <a href="#program_versions" class="slateblue">here</a> to.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#global_flags"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Global flags
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Global flags are compile-time flags that you can use,
    which will be appended to GNU configure runs.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">These flags are stored in the file global_flags.yml</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can either manually modify this file, or use
    commandline instructions to modify this file.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For example, if you wish to append <b>--disable-static</b>
    to all configure invocations via RBT, then you can issue
    the following command:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --add-global-flag=--disable-static
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --add-global-flag --disable-static
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Likewise, to remove a global flag, you can do:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --remove-global-flag=--disable-static
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --remove-global-flag --disable-static
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can reset all global flags again, by issuing:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --clear-global-flags
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that since as of March 2025, global-flags are
    slightly deprecated; they never were too terribly
    useful to begin with, from the point of view of
    the SoftwareManager project.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#optional_dependencies_for_the_softwaremanager_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Optional dependencies for the SoftwareManager-project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">The **wget gem** is recommended as an optional dependency for
    the SoftwareManager gem, but you can also use the SoftwareManager
    project without the wget gem just fine. In that case, if the wget
    gem is not available, the SoftwareManager project will attempt to
    use the wget binary via a **system()**-call, hence an "external"
    program, to ruby.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This requires the installation of **wget** e. g. from this
    URL (or from your package manager's repository), unless wget is
    already available on your local computer system:</span>
<br>
<br>
<a href="http:/ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/wget/?C=M;O=D">
http://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/wget/?C=M;O=D
</a>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Of course, most Linux systems will have "wget" available by
    default, so the above more applies towards operating systems such
    as windows (although more recent windows versions also include a
    linux-subsystem including bash, the **WSL**, so this should
    also not be a problem).</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#how_does_the_format_of_a_cookbook_recipe_the_respective_yml_file_look_like"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>How does the format of a cookbook recipe, the respective .yml file, look like?
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Each <b>cookbook entry</b> is just an <b>individual yaml file</b>,
    with the extension name being <b>.yml</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For instance, information about the programming language <b>ruby</b>
    will be stored in the file called <b>ruby.yml</b>; information about
    the programming language <b>python</b> will be stored in the file
    <b>python.yml</b>; information about the <b>mate-desktop</b> will
    be stored in the file <b>matedesktop.yml</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If there are any "-" tokens as part of the name,
    then these will be removed when RSM tries to determine
    the filename.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This <b>yaml file</b> should contain all the required
    information to get that particular program to install on
    a given system.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Additional information can be added as well, such as
    <b>maintainer(s)</b>, <b>extra information</b> of the
    program at hand, tips and hints in how to install or
    use the program, sed-modifications, pkgconfig files
    (aka .pc files) that are installed alongside with,
    patchsets that are to be applied, binaries, headers
    and libraries and so on and so forth.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">It can be a quite detailed file, mostly due to
    being able to allow some flexibility during
    installation.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Many programs "out in the wild" are <b>well-behaving</b>
    and will honour a <b>--prefix</b> variable given (or
    <b>-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=</b>, such as in use by
    programs that depend on <b>cmake</b>, for compilation).
    Such programs usually require <b>little to no
    modification</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Unfortunately, some other programs come with
    <b>flawed installation scripts</b>, hardcoded paths
    or workarounds that have to be employed to get these
    to work - very often sed-operations, such as done
    in the LFS project. Some programs may also have
    already become obsoleted, due to changes e. g. in
    glibc/gcc and other programs. If there is no
    maintainer of the downstream package then this
    normally means that other people have to either
    maintain that package; or provide patches to
    get this projects to work again.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">As <b>a reference project</b>, the <b>LFS project</b>
    provides a <b>lot</b> of useful information in how to
    get many programs to work. I consider the <b>LFS project</b>
    to be hugely important for the whole Linux ecosystem,
    much more important than the various different distributions.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">At any rate, let's now have a look at the <b>fish.yml</b>
    recipe, to give a specific example and explain that.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This <b>fish.yml</b> file will look like this, as
    of <b>February 2025</b>:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
fish:
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 binaries:
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 - fish
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 - fish_indent
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 - fish_key_reader
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 short_description: |
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  FISH is an interactive (commandline) shell.
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 description: |
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  FISH is the Friendly Interactive Shell, a smart and user-friendly
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  command line shell for macOS, Linux, and the rest of the family.
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 url1: https://github.com/fish-shell/fish-shell/releases/download/2.7.1/fish-2.7.1.tar.gz
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 url2: http://fishshell.com/files/2.1.0
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 url3: http://sourceforge.net/projects/fish/
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 homepage: http://fishshell.com/
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 tags:
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 - shell
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 prefix: f
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 keep_extracted: yes
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
 last_update: 10.02.2025
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The very first entry, on top, is the name of the
    program itself, in this case, <b>fish</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">While this part could in theory be omitted (since
    the name of the program is already stored as the
    first part of the very filename), I found that it
    is useful to have this entry within the file,
    primarily as a visual identifier if you work
    with it in an editor. It helps me a lot,
    for instance.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that no <b>-</b> or <b>_</b> characters are
    allowed there in this entry - it is really a
    stripped down name of the program at hand only.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If the name would be e. g. 'gtk-doc', with an URL
    such as **http://ftp.gnome.org/pub/gnome/sources/gtk-doc/1.26/gtk-doc-1.26.tar.xz**,
    then the name there for the gtkdoc.yml file would have
    to be **gtkdoc:** - thus, all '-' were removed.
    The name that appears there is also the name of
    the .yml file at hand. The .yml files may also not
    include any '-' or '_' characters. Do also note
    that while I am following this convention since
    many years, it may one day be changed to allow
    for '-' and '_'. But for the time being, the
    strict requirement is that we may not
    have '-' or '_' characters there.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Next, let's look at the entry **binaries:**.
    This entry tells us which binaries/executables
    this particular program will install. This also
    allows us to remove binaries in the /usr/bin/
    hierarchy, if you compiled into an AppDir
    prefix - for more information here, see
    class **SoftwareManager::PurgeBinariesOfThisProgram**.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The next entry is **short_description**, which
    is e. g. equivalent to slackware's pkg-format,
    as introduction to the specific program
    at hand, in a short notation.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Then we have the entry **main description**,
    followed by several **url** entries. The first
    url entry, aptly named **url1**, is the most
    important entry. It tells us where to find the
    archive to the program at hand.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This is ideal the URL to an existing archive, but
    it could also be a github repository, in principle.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Then we also have the <b>homepage</b> entry, which
    denotes the homepage of the program (or any other
    webpage that has relevant information, in the event
    that there no homepage entry exists for that
    particular program).</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Then we have <b>tags</b>: which just groups the
    program into popular <b>tag-classifiers</b>, such
    as "shell" in this case. Then the prefix in use,
    which is f for false, meaning "non-traditional"
    aka "appdir" prefix such as GoboLinux makes
    use of. Then there is the keep_extracted 
    setting, which tells us whether to keep the
    archive extracted or not after extracting/compiling
    it. Last but not least, the last_update tag tells
    us when this program was last updated. The default
    format here is dd.mm.yyy, but shortcuts are
    allowed. For example, Oct, for October, can
    be used rather than 10, and so on.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The next entry is <b>prefix</b>. This one is
    mostly synonymous for the --prefix= option given
    to GNU autoconfigure based projects.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">A prefix value of t means true, which stands for /usr/. A
    prefix value of f means false, which stands for the
    particular AppDir-like prefix. In the case here, for
    fish, this would expand to <b>/Programs/Fish/2.7.1</b>.
    GoboLinux uses a very similar AppDir layout by
    default, although with slightly different program
    names that can also be upcased, e. g. "KDE-Libs" 
    and so forth. (the RSM project will offer both variants
    here; the GoboLinux naming scheme, and the simpler
    scheme where only the first character is upcased,
    and the other characters are all downcased.)</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">There are many more entries, most of which
    should be documented under the doc/ subdirectory
    of this gem. What follows next are some more
    mentions of important (and less important)
    entries.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The entry <b>configure_base_dir: unix</b>
    determines which base directory is to be used.
    In the above example, RBT would cd into the
    directory called unix/. This is important for
    some programs such as <b>tk</b> or <b>xvid</b> -
    have a look at their directory structure
    to understand this setting.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Since as of December 2018 it is possible to
    use github URL that are truncated. Take the
    program <b>conky</b> as an example. It
    has an url like the following:</span>
<br>
<br>
<a href="https:/github.com/brndnmtthws/conky/archive/v1.11.0.tar.gz" class="BOLD marl2em">
https://github.com/brndnmtthws/conky/archive/v1.11.0.tar.gz
</a>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will now be automatically expanded into
    the correct naming scheme, aka **conky-1.11.0**.
    No idea why GitHub is not doing so on their own
    automatically; the tarball is even wrongly built,
    since it extracts to precisely that name after
    download. But anyway, ask GitHub about this,
    not me.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The content of these individual .yml files
    is essentially just a Hash that describes the
    various attributes of the given project at
    hand (and some additional information when it
    is required for installing/compiling this program).</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that since as of January 2020, you can
    also just provide a new URL and register a
    program this way anew.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Commandline Example for this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry http://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/kawa/kawa-3.1.tar.gz
</span><br>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#packaging_the_softwaremanager_scripts"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Packaging the SoftwareManager scripts
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can package all the latest SoftwareManager scripts
    by using a commandline flag such as this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry package_cookbooks
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --package_cookbooks
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will create a directory in <b>/depot/archives/</b>
    and package the SoftwareManager scripts into that
    directory.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Of course you can do so manually as well, but I wanted
    to have this functionality at the least available for
    when a user is on windows and may quickly and conveniently
    need to transfer the files, for whatever the reason(s).</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#remove_program"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Remove Program
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">To remove a program, you can use:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
remove_this_program
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">On GoboLinux this would be done via RemoveProgram.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#porg"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Porg
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can use the program called <b>porg</b> to
    install a program.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Porg will keep track of program files that are
    installed.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can also <b>disable porg</b> from the 
    commandline via:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --disable-porg
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --disable_porg
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --disableporg
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Or just directly edit the respective .yml file.</span>
<br>
</p>
