<h2>
<a href="#blfs_beyond_linux_from_scratch_and_also_lfs"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>BLFS - Beyond Linux From Scratch (and also LFS)
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em"><b>class SoftwareManager::Actions::Cookbooks::Blfs</b>
    has "support" for BLFS in that it will ... simply show
    a URL to the remote BLFS page of a given package, if
    it exists, on the commandline.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you only need to know the URL to the <b>BLFS homepage</b>,
    to embed it for display into a webpage perhaps or to merely
    display it onto the commandline, you can use the following
    simple <b>toplevel-API</b> for this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.blfs(:name_of_the_program_goes_in_here)
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.blfs(:openssl) # => "https://www.linuxfromscratch.org/blfs/view/8.1/postlfs/openssl.html"
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
# You can also use a String as input to the method rather than a Symbol:
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.blfs('ruby') # => 'https://www.linuxfromscratch.org/blfs/view/svn/general/ruby.html'
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will return the remote BLFS page, as URL (a <b>String</b>,
    actually), if it exists, and if it has been registered in the
    corresponding .yml file (cookbook file for the program at hand;
    in this example the file <b>openssl.yml</b>). If no BLFS entry
    has been registered then <b>nil</b> will be returned by this
    method.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can also use class <b>SoftwareManager::LFS</b> to
    build/create a LFS from scratch. This is presently (as of
    the year <b>2019</b>) quite incomplete, though, and will
    not work. Lots of different things have to be done in the
    correct sequence before a LFS can be built from scratch
    successfully, and possible errors have to be checked
    before the build can continue. In the long run, for the
    future, this will eventually work, one day - but for now
    it is an incomplete stub and not recommended for testing
    much at all. It is simpler to use the slow, semi-manual
    approach for now.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you wish to quickly <b>paste</b> the BLFS page
    of a given program onto the commandline, for display
    purpose, then you can do something like this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry php --parseblfs
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Since as of <b>September 2021</b> a bin/ script
    exists for this functionality. This was already
    planned back in <b>August 2019</b>, but I finally
    had a good use case (support for my older laptop)
    to add it. The executable is called
    <b>paste_blfs</b> and it can be used
    in the following way via the <b>commandline</b>:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
paste_blfs ruby
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
paste_blfs htop
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Since as of <b>December 2019</b>, it is
    now also possible to display, on the commandline,
    <b>any</b> registered BLFS entry. This will help
    in the event that you can not access the xorg-server
    at the moment, yet still require information for
    different packages (I faced exactly this
    problem, so I then added that functionality to
    the SoftwareManager project).</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In order for this to work, you evidently need
    to have a working <b>internet connection</b>
    available - but in principle, the information
    stored in the BLFS project could be zipped
    up and distributed too, within the 
    SoftwareManager project.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For the time being, though, only pasting
    is supported - there is no plan to bundle
    the information into the SoftwareManager
    project at this point in time.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Usage example for this functionality
    follows:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --parse-blfs-page-for=llvm
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In <b>December 2019</b> another feature
    was added - the ability to make use of 
    the BLFS instructions directly, and run
    them.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The idea here is that the user may wish to compile some
    program from source, but may not access a working xorg-server,
    as you are working on the commandline only.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Invocation example for this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry kerberos --use-blfs-instructions # Compile
    kerberos in the BLFS way.
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Since LFS/BLFS is such a useful project, the 
    SoftwareManager suite has some more support in
    this regard. This is rather unsurprising, as the
    <b>Linux From Scratch</b> (LFS) Project has
    instructions on how to compile programs from
    source. So it has a somehwat similar meta-goal,
    like the SoftwareManager project.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">These instructions are immensely useful. A
    lot of the information from LFS/BLFS was
    integrated into the SoftwareManager project.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Many individual cookbook yaml files
    can point towards the LFS/BLFS page,
    which will often contain additional 
    useful information in case you get
    stuck with something.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can try to show this URL by
    doing this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
blfs curl
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This would show the BLFS remote
    URL of the program called <b>curl</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can also directly paste the
    content of the remote BLFS webpage onto
    the terminal, if there is a remote
    BLFS page associated with a given program.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The way to do this is as follows:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gcc --paste-blfs-page
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you want to show all programs that
    have a blfs entry, use the following command:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --show-programs-with-a-blfs-entry
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you want to obtain an Array of
    all programs containing a BLFS entry,
    you can use the following toplevel API:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.return_all_blfs_entries
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This is currently rather slow; I'll look
    into making it faster in the future,
    making use of grep.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you want to find out how many BLFS
    entries are registered in the RSM project,
    use this toplevel method:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.n_BLFS_entries? # => 776 - as of March 2025
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#minimal_chroot_environment_and_improved_chroot_environments"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Minimal chroot environment and improved chroot environments
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">On my home system I tend to have a working backup
    system at <b>/depot/chroot/</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In this directory I tend to have all important programs
    "duplicated", so that I can safely re-compile when
    necessary.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Which compile-chain may be used to build up a
    minimal chroot?</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">I will try to list the options here, as I use
    this on my system (or a new system):</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry make --static --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry bash --static --chroot # <- This may already suffice.
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry mpfr --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gmp --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry mpc --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry sed --static --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry grep --static --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry coreutils --static --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry ruby --dontuseconfigureoptions --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry python --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gawk --chroot --static
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nano --static --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
# Generate my custom rc-files next:
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
rcfiles --populate-this-dir=/depot/chroot/AUTOGENERATED/
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
rcfiles
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
rcfiles --populate-this-dir=/AUTOGENERATED/
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gcc --chroot --dont-symlink
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry ncurses --dontuseconfigureoptions --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry zlib --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nano --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry bison --static --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry m4 --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry curl --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry isl --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry flex --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry nasm --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gc --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry tar --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry texinfo --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry openssl --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry libelf --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry elfutils --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry ccache --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry lzma  --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry cmake --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry file --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry pkgconfig --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gperf --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry popt --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry git --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry pcre1 --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry pcre2 --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry libunistring --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gettext --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry check --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry libxml2 --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry mtools --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry gzip --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry doxygen --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry strace --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry valgrind --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry graphite2 --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry tcl --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry expect --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry dejagnu --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry patch --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry libogg --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry sqlite --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry libpciaccess --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry libdrm --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry pixman --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry llvm --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry enchant --chroot
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
# Compiling glibc should come last here:
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry glibc --chroot --do-not-symlink --do-not-run-ldconfig
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Do not forget to also copy a statically compiled version
    of busybox.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Also, if the chroot-command fails, make sure that
    you have copied the ld-linux shared objects, such as:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
'/lib64/ld-linux.so.2' -> './ld-linux.so.2'
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
'/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2' -> './ld-linux-x86-64.so.2'
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In March 2025 it was realised that the above steps
    are a bit brittle, so it made sense to think of an
    alternative approach: by making use of SoftwareManager
    to enable the individual early steps used by LFS. These
    early steps will properly set up a chrooted environment,
    which is then used to compile the rest of a Linux
    system. Thus, SoftwareManager will be adjusted to
    allow for these individual steps as well.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#auto_resolve_compile_related_problems_via_the_softwaremanager_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Auto-resolve compile-related problems via the SoftwareManager project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Since as of <b>September 2017</b>, the 
    <b>SoftwareManager scripts</b> can also
    give some advice how to resolve some
    compile-related problems.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This is currently fairly minimal, but it will be extended
    subsequently in the future. It was also a reason why the
    namespace Libtool has been integrated into SoftwareManager,
    as <b>SoftwareManager::Libtool</b>. This allows
    us to auto-correct some libtool-related problems and
    keep all libtool-related code within that namespace.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#module_programs_making_use_of_the_extended_cookbook_dataset"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Module programs: making use of the extended cookbook dataset
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em"><b>Module programs</b> refers to the ability to access
    all registered programs that are reigstered in the SoftwareManager
    project, at the <b>toplevel</b> "SoftwareManager." namespace. In
    other words, we can "copy" the program names onto the 
    SoftwareManager top-level module "namespace".</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For instance, <b>htop</b> would be available at</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.htop
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">if it is called as a "module program".</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Take note that this is <b>NOT</b> the default
    behaviour. By default, the above way to call the
    method .htop() on SoftwareManager would not work.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">As another example: the program <b>binutils</b>
    would, as a module program, be available at:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.binutils
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">And so on, and so forth. No "-" characters
    are allowed there, as these are not allowed
    in methods written in ruby.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that this will return a sanitized Hash
    that holds all the information required to
    compile the given program from source - this
    dataset thus describes these programs. That
    information may still have to be interpreted
    by a program, of course.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Simply require the necessary file for this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
  require 'software_manager/module_programs'
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">After that, the above methods will work. Let's
    see a few more examples for this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.wayland
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.ruby
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.php
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.gnomemimedata
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.evince
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that <b>reader methods</b> via '?'
    character are available too, although this
    could be toggled. The '?' will access the
    datastructure as a <b>Hash</b> rather
    than a specialized object.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Invoke it like so:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.htop? # => {"archive_size"=>323560,
    "short_description"=>"ncurses-based interactive process viewer.", "github"=>nil, "set_env_variables"=>{"LDFLAGS"=>"-ltinfow"}, "homepage"=>"http://hisham.hm/htop/", "binaries"=>["htop"], "headers"=>[], "libraries"=>[], "postinstall"=>[], "pre_make_commands"=>[], "required_deps_on"=>["glibc => 2.3.2", "ncurses => 5.6"], "tags"=>[], "pkgconfig_files"=>[],
    "program_path"=>"/home/x/src/htop/htop-2.0.2.tar.xz", "program_full_name"=>"htop-2.0.2.tar.xz" ... and so forth }
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This functionality exists primarily because it may
    be easier for you to use the above API calls.
    Internally though, the SoftwareManager project
    will prefer API calls such as
    <b>SoftwareManager::Cookbooks::Cookbook.new :htop</b>
    instead.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that the above works without any '-' as part of
    the name, so there will not be
    <b>SoftwareManager.gnome-mime-data()</b> - it would be
    <b>SoftwareManager.gnomemimedata()</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">When may you want to use this? Well, it could
    be used if you do want to use a simpler API. It
    is very easy to remember, too: just use
    'SoftwareManager.' followed by the name
    of the program, without any '-' or '_'
    characters there.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#how_to_register_all_programs"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>How to register all programs
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">It may be that you want to register all programs in
    the yaml database that is supported by the
    SoftwareManager project.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In order to do so, run this command:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --register_all_programs
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --rap
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#batch_updating_all_registered_gems_in_the_softwaremanager_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Batch-updating all registered gems in the SoftwareManager project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can batch-update all registered gems via</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
rsm --update-all-gems
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that this will only work if the corresponding
    .gem is part of the Cookbooks submodule of this
    project.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#updating_all_registered_rubygems"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Updating all registered rubygems
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">It is possible to <b>batch-update</b> all
    <b>registered rubygems</b> via:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --update-all-gems
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The boolean constant <b>ALSO_AUTOMATICALLY_INSTALL_THE_UPDATED_GEM</b>,
    defined in class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager, controls
    whether the updated gems will automatically be installed by the
    SoftwareManager project. If set to true then the SoftwareManager
    project will not only download the respective gem, but
    also install it. Since not everyone may want this, the
    constant handles this case for the time being - I personally
    like this constant set to true, since it saves me some keystrokes
    in the long run.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you do not want to, or can not, update all
    registered .gem entries, yet you still want to
    install the .gem files that are registered,
    then you can use this commandline invocation variant:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --install-all-rubygems
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will install all registered .gem files, in
    an alphabetical manner. Dependencies will not be
    checked that way, but in principle if all .gem
    have been properly registered in the Cookbooks
    submodule, then this batch-gem installation
    should work just fine.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#modifying_the_cookbook_dataset_via_a_webpage"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Modifying the cookbook-dataset via a webpage
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">In the past, already since as of <b>13.09.2007</b>,
    it was possible to modify the cookbook-dataset
    via webpages - usually via a .cgi webpage.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">As of March 2025 this is no longer possible, 
    but it may be brought back one day. Stay tuned in this
    regard.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#patches_to_the_cookbook_dataset_and_applying_those_patches_automatically"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Patches to the cookbook-dataset and applying those patches automatically
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Some programs sometimes need a patch, in order for
    successful compilation.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The entry that is to be used here, in a corresponding .yml file,
    used to be <b>apply_patch:</b>. Since as of 2025, this is
    now simply called <b>patch:</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">It is to be used like this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
patch:
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
- https://connie.slackware.com/~alien/slackbuilds/id3lib/build/id3lib-3.8.3_gcc4.diff
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This feature is not that important, but sometimes a program
    may need a patch, so the feature had to be added, in order
    to allow users to automatically download and apply such
    patches, before compilation begins in earnest.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#the_functionality_of_class_programinformation"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>The functionality of class ProgramInformation
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">ProgramInformation is a fairly small class.
    The motto behind it is to
    <b>do one thing well.</b></span>
<br>
<br>
<script>
$(function() {

  if (typeof global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === 'undefined' || global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === null) {
    $( "#drag_q4vfohv" ).draggable()
  }
  else {
    if (global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop) {
      $( "#drag_q4vfohv" ).draggable()
    }
    else {
      $( "#drag_q4vfohv" ).draggable({ disabled: true })
    }
  }
});


</script>

<img src="https://i.imgur.com/q4VfoHv.png" class="marl3em round_black3" id="drag_q4vfohv" draggable="true">
</p>
<h3>
<a href="#the_two_methods_first_and_last_part_of_class_programinformation"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>The two methods .first and .last, part of class ProgramInformation
</h3>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">It is possible to obtain the name of a given program at hand,
    and the associated version, like so:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
require 'software_manager/requires/program_information.rb'
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
x = SoftwareManager::Actions::ProgramInformation.new('ruby-2.5.0')
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
puts x.first # => ruby
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
puts x.last
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that other toplevel variants exist as well, such as:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.return_name()
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.return_version()
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The idea here is <b>to be as flexible as possible</b>, so
    that the user cherry-pick whatever is preferred. Personally
    I usually use the toplevel method variants, as these
    are shorter to type.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h3>
<a href="#tests_for_softwaremanageractionsprograminformation"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Tests for SoftwareManager::Actions::ProgramInformation
</h3>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">class ProgramInformation is very important to automatically
    determine the program-name and the program-version of a
    given String.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">As this class is very important, it also comes with
    a test suite. These tests are stored mostly in the
    file called <b>software_manager/test/testing_program_information.rb</b>,
    which will test the Array called
    <b>SoftwareManager::ProgramInformation::ARRAY_TEST_THIS_AS_INPUT</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Not all tests may work perfectly well, but for
    the most likely input it should work fine. So
    like 98% of all use cases that a user or developer
    may ever encounter. It should do well.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#module_softwaremanageractionsvalidations"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>module SoftwareManager::Actions::Validations
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em"><b>module SoftwareManager::Actions::Validations</b> has
    been added in January 2025. The main objective of this
    module is to gather all validations in one place.
    Validations in this regard means quality-control code -
    in other words, code that can be used to improve the
    quality of the whole codebase in the SoftwareManager
    suite.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#handling_errors_in_the_softwaremanager_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Handling errors in the SoftwareManager project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Some problems and errors may happen during compilation
    or installation of programs.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Before this statement is further explained, let's briefly review
    how to disable checking for errors in the SoftwareManager project
    automatically. You can use the following commandline flag for
    disabling error checking:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --no-error-checking
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This allows the user to bypass error-checking for
    the current compilation run. Let's have a look at
    the feature to <b>autocorrect</b> some errors.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In the past, the SoftwareManager suite handled errors
    mostly via the toplevel area, that is, into the namespace
    <b>module SoftwareManager</b>, as well as an ad-hoc
    registry of common errors and problems. These were
    handled via one, or several, toplevel instance variables.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This approach was changed in 2025. Specifically we
    now first register all known errors and problems;
    this step is not yet reasonably complete. Once
    it has progressed more, the SoftwareManager suite
    will attempt to handle some of these errors
    automatically - or at the least give the user an
    option to decide on his or her own how to
    handle these errors and problems.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In the past, we registered the problems into the
    toplevel, and then allowed a toplevel-API such as:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
SoftwareManager.error_message?
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">to show these.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Note that this used to be reset to nil,
    its <b>default value</b>, whenever a new program
    is compiled.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In April 2024 this was changed. First, we will finish
    by <b>detecting</b> all errors and problems. Once that
    is done, we will add code that will try to fix such
    problems.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Sometimes it may not be wanted to stop on errors,
    in particular if the error reported is not a real
    error. Thus, the user needs to have a way to
    overrule this behaviour, which can be done by
    the following commandline flag:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --dont-stop-on-errors
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --ignore-errors
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The latter commandline flag still works in 2025 by the
    way; I sometimes have to use it to bypass wrongfully
    reported errors.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This would instruct
    <b>SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager</b>
    to <b>not</b> stop on errors and instead (try to)
    continue.</span>
<br>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#autocorrecting_some_errors_in_regards_to_the_softwaremanager_project"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Autocorrecting some errors in regards to the SoftwareManager project
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">The various SoftwareManager scripts can attempt to auto-correct
    some errors. This is currently a feature that is to be tested
    more thoroughly; it may not work flawlessly yet.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The errors that the SoftwareManager project can
    auto-correct are mostly related to <b>libtool</b>
    right now.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If the file <b>use_autofixing.yml</b> contains a String called
    t or true, meaning "enable autofixing", then auto-correcting will be
    used.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">There is another option that has to be set to true though,
    which is the "is_on_roebe?" settings, which indicates my
    home directory use.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Presently (Sep 2017) this option does not work too reliably,
    so it is still tested. You can test it too though if you
    enable "is_on_roebe".</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">In 2025 I decided to adjust the above a little; auto-fixing
    issues will still be a desired feature, but first we really
    need to document all existing errors and problems, and handle
    these. Only then should we begin to extend the auto-fixing
    part of the SoftwareManager project.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#querying_the_prefix_to_be_used"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Querying the prefix to be used
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">If you have the need to find out the prefix that
    will be used, you can issue the following query:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry htop prefix?
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry htop --prefix?
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#class_softwaremanageractionsgitty"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>class SoftwareManager::Actions::Gitty
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em"><b>class SoftwareManager::Gitty</b> is a helper class. It
    ultimately wraps over the "--gitty" commandline instruction
    class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager uses.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The SoftwareManager::Actions::Gitty class can be
    used to quickly checkout the git sources of a
    remote project.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">So, for instance, if you want to check out
    the latest source code of mesa, you could do
    this via the commandline:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
gitty mesa
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will download mesa and repackage it to
    today's timestamp, in <b>dd.mm.yyyy</b> notation.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can download any program that is registered in
    the SoftwareManager namespace, if it has a corresponding
    entry called <b>git_url</b> in the .yml file. This is
    how I maintain this list: I simply change the associated
    git URL, such as for github or gitlab, in the
    corresponding .yml file.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Since as of <b>March 2024</b> gitty was slightly
    extended, in that it can now work on any arbitrary
    remote URL that you pass into this class.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For instance:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
gitty https://github.com/kennylevinsen/seatd
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This would download the current git sources
    from that remote URL, and repackage it automatically
    for you, using a dd.mm.yyyy notation. This
    functionality was added because I sometimes found
    new programs and just wanted to quickly test
    whether I can compile it, so I can now just
    copy/paste this URL onto the commandline, as
    input for <b>gitty</b>.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#softwaremanageractionsoftwaremanager"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em"><b>class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager</b>
    was added in March 2024. It has replaced the older
    class called <b>Installer</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The key idea behind <b>SoftwareManager</b>, aside from
    fixing a few smaller bugs and issues, will be to
    transition into an action-based system.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This means that everything that is important,
    to be done by class SoftwareManager, should be
    handled through the method called
    <b>SoftwareManager.action()</b> primarily.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The advantage of this approach is that we can
    easily change aspects of class SoftwareManager,
    without having to modify the class directly.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This replacement effort is complete as of 2025.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h3>
<a href="#class_softwaremanageractionsoftwaremanager_feedback_the_url_of_various_programs_at_the_same_time"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager: feedback the URL of various programs at the same time
</h3>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">Say that you <b>wish to find out the URL to various
    programs at the same time</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can use this the following commandline
    invocation for this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --url-for-these-programs=php,ruby,python,m4,php
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will show a result such as:</span>
<br>
<script>
$(function() {

  if (typeof global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === 'undefined' || global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop === null) {
    $( "#drag_f9ya9vr" ).draggable()
  }
  else {
    if (global_variable_allow_global_drag_and_drop) {
      $( "#drag_f9ya9vr" ).draggable()
    }
    else {
      $( "#drag_f9ya9vr" ).draggable({ disabled: true })
    }
  }
});


</script>

<img src="https://i.imgur.com/F9yA9vr.png" class="round_black1" id="drag_f9ya9vr" style="margin: 1em; margin-left: 4em;" draggable="true">
<br>
<span class="l1em">Entries that are included more than once - such as php
    in the above made-up example - will only be shown once.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h3>
<a href="#class_softwaremanageractionsoftwaremanager_the_commandline_option_compile_the_first_entry_in_the_current_working_directory"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager - the commandline option --compile-the-first-entry-in-the-current-working-directory
</h3>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">On my computer system I have done the following alias:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
this → rbt --compile-the-first-entry-in-the-current-working-directory
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">So, I can then navigate to a directory containing a
    source archive that can be compiled. Then I type "this"
    and hit enter. <b>SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager</b>
    will proceed to compile the first entry of this directory.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This allows the user to be lazy and efficient. The above
    instruction will simply compile the very first entry in any
    given directory, without having to type the name or
    even write the beginning of the name and use '*' as
    substitution character, such as via:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry php*.xz
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry tar*.xz
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">I recommend that users of the SoftwareManager suite
    also use an alias such as "this", but of course this
    is up to that user, not to me. For me, personally,
    just typing "this" is very convenient should I need
    it.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h3>
<a href="#internals_of_class_softwaremanageractionsoftwaremanager"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Internals of class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager
</h3>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em"><b>class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager</b> is the
    main class of the SoftwareManager-project, as it allows
    the user to compile or install a program from source.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">It is, more or less, <b>the central entry point to the
    SoftwareManager project</b> - even though you can invoke
    the other .rb files directly, SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager
    often provides a simpler convenience access means to the
    disparate functions that constitute the SoftwareManager-project.
    This class integrates other classes, sort of like
    a <b>glue</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This subsection here will explain a few key decisions
    made, in the long run; and will also explain a few
    internals used by this class.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Do not worry if this may be a bit confusing at first -
    it is meant primarily for me, and for others who
    may want to extend the SoftwareManager-project one day.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The method set_configure_base_directory(), is used
    to determine the directory where the configure script
    ought to reside. That way we can enter a separate
    build directory yet still be able to invoke
    configure (or cmake) at the right directory target.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h3>
<a href="#some_commandline_options_for_class_softwaremanageractionsoftwaremanager_explained"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Some commandline options for class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager explained
</h3>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">As was already written down somewhere else in this
    document, you can pass in several commandline options
    to <b>class SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager</b>.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">You can also use commandline options that include
    <b>--</b> and these options can overrule other
    configure options, on an ad-hoc basis.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">For instance, let's assume that the configure options
    in a given yaml file, such as <b>weechat.yml</b>, include
    an option such as <b>--enable-gtk</b>. But you don't want
    any GTK GUI for Weechat. So either you modify the .yml
    file, or you decide to override this flag, on the
    commandline, by doing:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry weechat --disable-gtk
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This will now overrule the setting in the
    weechat.yml file for the given compilation run,
    and compile weechat with gtk <b>disabled</b>.
    That way you can leave weechat.yml unmodified,
    yet you are still able to get the desired
    change. (For a permanent change you would
    have to modify the .yml file of course.)</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">If you want to get a quick overview, issue:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry --overview
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This should give a brief overview over
    the available utility scripts.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Sometimes you may not want to pick up the
    <b>configure options</b> from a specific .yml
    file. In this event, you can pass in the option
    <b>--dont-use-configure-options</b> to
    avoid doing so.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Usage examples for this approach:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry htop --dont-use-configure-options
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry glib --user-home-prefix --use-meson --no-configure-options
</span><br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry ruby --do-not-use-any-configure-options
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">This allows the user to just use the "barebones"
    compilation mode; it may be helpful for users who
    encounter errors due to the use of some configure
    options or some combination of configure options
    used.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#working_with_meson"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Working with meson
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can specifically enable the meson-build by issuing this:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry glib --use-meson
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#check_for_software_that_is_locally_available"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>Check for software that is locally available
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">You can check for the latest packages locally via</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
ry htop latest
</span><br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#configure_command_to_use"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>configure_command_to_use
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">This short subsection is to briefly explain the
    option called <b>configure_command_to_use</b> that
    is available for individual cookbook .yml files.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">By default, this command can be omitted, and
    will then default to <b>./configure</b> - aka
    <b>GNU configure</b>. This should cover most
    programs.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">There are some programs that do not use
    GNU configure, though, in particular cmake-based
    projects, scons, waf, meson/ninja and so forth.
    These are handled separately for the most part.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">There are, however had, <b>also</b> programs
    that use their own custom and unique build system,
    often defaulting to some shell script. The 
    <b>SoftwareManager-project</b> thus has to
    be flexible here and allow for custom
    shell scripts to be used as well.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">An example for this can be seen in the file
    <b>discount.yml</b> for the program <b>discount</b>.
    If you look at that file you can see the
    following line:</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="marl2em BOLD">
configure_command_to_use: ./configure.sh
</span><br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">It thus specifies that
    <b>SoftwareManager::Action::SoftwareManager</b>
    will make use of that <b>configure.sh</b>
    shell scripts rather than the more
    generic <b>configure</b> invocation run.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Some other programs use other
    <b>configure_command_to_use settings</b>;
    a recursive grep can find these, should
    a user be interested in that.</span>
<br>
</p>
<h2>
<a href="#class_softwaremanageractionssimplifyrootentriesinthismakefile"><img src="../../../../../data/images/standard_images/DOT_09.png" class="marr10px"></a>class SoftwareManager::Actions::SimplifyRootEntriesInThisMakefile
</h2>
<p class="default">
<span class="l1em">This very specialized class will replace all root:root
    entries in a file, such as a <b>Makefile</b>, with 0:0
    entries.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">The reason why this small class was added was primarily
    because sometimes the host system may be partially broken,
    and only display 0:0 rather than root. This may happen
    more frequently in a chrooted environment.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Oddly enough, this may then lead to errors during
    compilation or installation, which was the primary
    reason why this class was created: I wanted to ignore
    these issues.</span>
<br>
<br>
<span class="l1em">Since I was tired of such Makefiles failing on me,
    this class was written in <b>August of 2019</b>. It
    is not a very important or commonly used class, though.</span>
<br>
</p>
<br>
